description: Validating consistency between NDA templates and company confidentiality policies
expected_issues: Confidential information definition varies between documents
Duration of confidentiality obligations differs: NDA states 3 years, Policy states 5 years, Employment Contract states indefinite
Return of materials requirements are contradictory

documents.title: Standard Non-Disclosure Agreement Template
documents.content:
MUTUAL NON-DISCLOSURE AGREEMENT

This Mutual Non-Disclosure Agreement ("Agreement") is entered into as of [DATE] ("Effective Date") by and between:

[COMPANY NAME], a company incorporated in Hong Kong ("Disclosing Party")
AND
[RECIPIENT NAME] ("Receiving Party")

1. DEFINITION OF CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION

"Confidential Information" means any information disclosed by one party to the other party, either directly or indirectly, in writing, orally, or by inspection of tangible objects, including without limitation:

a) Business plans, strategies, and forecasts
b) Financial information, pricing, and cost data
c) Customer and supplier lists and information
d) Technical data, specifications, and designs
e) Software, algorithms, and source code
f) Marketing plans and strategies
g) Any information marked as "Confidential" or similar designation

Confidential Information does NOT include information that:
- Was known to Receiving Party prior to disclosure
- Is or becomes publicly available through no breach of this Agreement
- Is independently developed by Receiving Party without use of Confidential Information
- Is rightfully received from a third party without confidentiality restrictions

2. OBLIGATIONS

The Receiving Party agrees to:
a) Hold all Confidential Information in strict confidence
b) Not disclose Confidential Information to any third party without prior written consent
c) Use Confidential Information only for the purpose of [BUSINESS PURPOSE]
d) Protect Confidential Information with the same degree of care used for its own confidential information, but no less than reasonable care
e) Limit access to employees with a legitimate need to know

3. TERM AND TERMINATION

This Agreement shall commence on the Effective Date and continue for a period of two (2) years. The confidentiality obligations shall survive termination of this Agreement for an additional three (3) years, meaning Confidential Information must be kept confidential for a total of five (5) years from the date of initial disclosure.

4. RETURN OF MATERIALS

Upon termination or at any time upon request, the Receiving Party shall promptly:
- Return all Confidential Information in tangible form
- Destroy all copies, notes, and derivatives
- Certify in writing that all materials have been returned or destroyed

Exception: Legal or regulatory requirements to retain information

5. NO LICENSE OR RIGHTS

Nothing in this Agreement grants any license or rights in any Confidential Information, intellectual property, or other proprietary rights of the Disclosing Party.

6. REMEDIES

The Receiving Party acknowledges that breach of this Agreement may cause irreparable harm for which monetary damages are insufficient. The Disclosing Party shall be entitled to seek injunctive relief in addition to all other available remedies.

7. GOVERNING LAW

This Agreement shall be governed by the laws of Hong Kong SAR.

documents.title: Company Confidentiality and Information Security Policy
documents.content:
CONFIDENTIALITY AND INFORMATION SECURITY POLICY

Policy Number: SEC-001
Effective Date: January 10, 2024
Last Review: January 10, 2024

1. PURPOSE AND SCOPE

This policy establishes requirements for protecting company confidential information and trade secrets. All employees, contractors, consultants, and third parties with access to company information must comply.

2. CLASSIFICATION OF INFORMATION

Public: Information approved for public disclosure

Internal Use: Information for internal business use, not for external distribution without approval

Confidential: Sensitive business information requiring protection, including:
- Business strategies and plans
- Financial data (non-public)
- Customer information and contracts
- Employee personal data
- Vendor and supplier agreements
- Marketing and sales strategies

Highly Confidential / Trade Secrets: Most sensitive information, including:
- Proprietary technology and source code
- Research and development information
- Unreleased products and features
- M&A and corporate transactions
- Executive compensation
- Trade secrets and proprietary methodologies

3. HANDLING CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION

All personnel must:
✓ Access confidential information only when necessary for job duties
✓ Store confidential information securely (encrypted storage)
✓ Not disclose confidential information to unauthorized persons
✓ Use confidential information only for authorized business purposes
✓ Mark documents containing confidential information appropriately
✓ Dispose of confidential information securely (shredding, secure deletion)

4. DISCLOSURE TO THIRD PARTIES

Before disclosing confidential information to external parties:
- Obtain appropriate approvals (Legal/Management)
- Ensure NDA is executed
- Limit disclosure to minimum necessary
- Use secure transmission methods
- Track and log all disclosures

5. DURATION OF CONFIDENTIALITY

Employees' confidentiality obligations continue indefinitely, even after termination of employment. Information that constitutes trade secrets must remain confidential for as long as it maintains trade secret status.

For third parties under NDA, confidentiality obligations typically continue for 5 years after disclosure, unless the information constitutes a trade secret.

6. EMPLOYEE OBLIGATIONS UPON DEPARTURE

When employment ends, employees must:
- Return all company property, documents, and devices
- Delete all company information from personal devices
- Confirm in writing that all materials have been returned or destroyed
- Continue to maintain confidentiality of all company information

Note: Some company information (especially trade secrets) must remain confidential indefinitely.

7. BREACH AND CONSEQUENCES

Unauthorized disclosure of confidential information may result in:
- Disciplinary action up to and including termination
- Legal action to recover damages
- Injunctive relief to prevent further disclosure
- Criminal prosecution if applicable

8. REPORTING INCIDENTS

Any suspected or actual breach of confidentiality must be immediately reported to:
- Your manager
- IT Security (security@company.com)
- Legal Department (legal@company.com)

9. POLICY REVIEW

This policy is reviewed annually and updated as necessary to address evolving security threats and business requirements.

documents.title: Employment Contract - Confidentiality Clause
documents.content:
ARTICLE 12: CONFIDENTIALITY AND NON-DISCLOSURE

12.1 DEFINITION

For purposes of this Agreement, "Confidential Information" includes but is not limited to:

a) All information relating to the Employer's business operations, including financial information, business plans, strategies, forecasts, and budgets

b) Customer and client information, including names, contact details, requirements, and transaction history

c) Technical information, including processes, methods, techniques, formulas, compositions, systems, and research and development activities

d) Trade secrets, proprietary information, and intellectual property

e) Employee information and compensation details

f) Any information marked or designated as confidential

g) Any information that a reasonable person would understand to be confidential based on the nature of the information or circumstances of disclosure

12.2 OBLIGATIONS DURING EMPLOYMENT

The Employee agrees that during the term of employment:

a) The Employee shall not, without the prior written consent of the Employer, disclose any Confidential Information to any third party

b) The Employee shall use Confidential Information only for the purpose of performing duties under this Agreement

c) The Employee shall take all reasonable precautions to prevent unauthorized disclosure of Confidential Information

d) The Employee shall immediately notify the Employer of any unauthorized disclosure or suspected breach

12.3 OBLIGATIONS AFTER TERMINATION

The Employee's confidentiality obligations shall survive termination of employment and continue indefinitely. The Employee agrees:

a) Not to use or disclose Confidential Information for any purpose after termination

b) To return all documents, materials, devices, and data containing or relating to Confidential Information within 3 business days of termination

c) To delete all Confidential Information from any personal devices or storage

d) To provide written certification of compliance with return and deletion requirements

12.4 EXCEPTIONS

The obligations under this Article shall not apply to information that:

- Was already known to the Employee before employment
- Becomes publicly available through no fault of the Employee
- Is independently developed by the Employee without reference to Confidential Information after termination
- Is disclosed pursuant to legal or regulatory requirement (with prior notice to Employer if possible)

12.5 PERMITTED DISCLOSURES

The Employee may disclose Confidential Information:

- To other employees who need to know for legitimate business purposes
- As required by law or court order (with advance notice to Employer if practicable)
- With express written authorization from the Employer

12.6 REMEDIES

The Employee acknowledges that:

a) Breach of confidentiality obligations will cause irreparable harm to the Employer

b) Monetary damages alone may be inadequate remedy

c) The Employer shall be entitled to seek injunctive relief, specific performance, and any other equitable remedies

d) The Employer may also pursue claims for damages, including consequential damages and lost profits

e) The Employee may be personally liable for any losses caused by unauthorized disclosure

12.7 NO LIMITATION ON OTHER OBLIGATIONS

This confidentiality clause is in addition to, and does not limit, any other confidentiality obligations the Employee may have under:

- Company policies and procedures
- Separate non-disclosure agreements
- Industry regulations or professional codes of conduct
- Common law duties of confidence and fidelity

12.8 SURVIVAL

This Article 12 shall survive termination of this Agreement and continue in full force and effect indefinitely.
